items.title: DefaultAzureCredential no longer allows a custom `client_id` parameter to be passed in

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: customer-reported
labels.description: Issues that are reported by GitHub users external to the Azure organization.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
- **Package Name**: azure-identity
- **Package Version**:  1.4.0
- **Operating System**: Any
- **Python Version**: Any

**Describe the bug**
`DefaultAzureCredential` no longer allows a custom `client_id` parameter to be passed in. This change is currently hard-coding the lookup of the `AZURE_CLIENT_ID` environment variable regardless of whether it is found in `kwargs`: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/c6388a01fc731ba8fba3de122aec799c384f59da/sdk/identity/azure-identity/azure/identity/_credentials/default.py#L103

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1.  try to create an instance of `DefaultAzureCredential(client_id=some_id)`

**Expected behavior**
I would expect to overwrite the default behavior of looking up the environment variable.

**Screenshots**
N/A

**Additional context**
This is particularly tricky on machines with multiple identities.

Initially asked about this here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/issues/10931#issuecomment-673016243 and was told to file a bug :)

items.body:
- **Package Name**: 
azure-common==1.1.25
azure-core==1.8.0
azure-identity==1.4.0
azure-keyvault-certificates==4.1.0
azure-keyvault-keys==4.1.0
azure-keyvault-secrets==4.1.0
azure-storage-blob==12.3.2

- **Operating System**:
ubuntu 18.04

- **Python Version**: 
Python 3.7.7 (default, Jun  9 2020, 18:08:39) 
[GCC 8.3.0] on linux

**Describe the bug**
Using AKS with VMSS and an Azure Identity user assigned. Any time I get a secret I also get this message. This is a non-fatal event and the code retrieves the secret and continues on.

`EnvironmentCredential.get_token failed: EnvironmentCredential authentication unavailable. Environment variables are not fully configured.`

No system variables are set for the azure credential authentication. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1.  AKS cluster with VMSS with user assigned identity no in same resource group as cluster. 
2. Launch python and get secret from azure vault.

```
from azure.identity import DefaultAzureCredential
from azure.keyvault.secrets import SecretClient

credential = DefaultAzureCredential()
secret_client = SecretClient(vault_url="https://XXXXXXX.vault.azure.net", credential=credential)
secret_client.get_secret('XXXXX').value
```

**Expected behavior**
Secret without odd message that doesn't make sense when not using environment variables.

**Additional context**
I'm going to verify this happens with a base python container and report back.

items.body:
- **Package Name**: 
azure-servicebus
- **Package Version**: 
0.50.3
- **Operating System**:
Windows 10
- **Python Version**: 
3.7.7

**Describe the bug**
Setting of scheduled enqueue time via `azure.servicebus.Message.schedule` is not reflected in `azure.servicebus.Message.scheduled_enqueue_time`.

**To Reproduce**
```
import azure.servicebus as sb
message = sb.Message('hi there!')
import datetime as dt
message.schedule(dt.datetime.now(dt.timezone.utc)+dt.timedelta(minutes=5))
message.scheduled_enqueue_time
```

**Expected behavior**
`azure.servicebus.Message.scheduled_enqueue_time` should reflect the time set using 
`azure.servicebus.Message.schedule`.

items.title: Clarify the no-body logs

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
This is the way the network logger is logging the body:
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/0021b7b0ba4ee9276f6313631373b0e2d6f584a4/sdk/core/azure-core/azure/core/pipeline/policies/_universal.py#L292

This might be confusing, to make an explicit difference between "there was no body, it was None" and "there was a 4 bytes body with the letters N-o-n-e" ([example](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.python/issues/733)).

The latter is actually something that could happen, if any layer is doing an incorrect `str(None)` at some point in the code, and debugging using pure loggers will be complicated.

This issue is about splitting explicitly the `None` body as a separate line, something like:
```python
elif request.body is None:
    _LOGGER.debug("This request has no body")
else:
    _LOGGER.debug(str(http_request.body))
```

items.title: HttpLoggingPolicy should acknowledge the existence of a body

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

items.body:
By design, HttpLoggingPolicy does not log the body of the request. However, this makes debugging complicated in some scenario, when we want at least to know if _any_ body has been sent.

This issue is about adding something like:
```python
                if isinstance(http_request.body, types.GeneratorType):
                    _LOGGER.info("File upload")
                elif http_request.body:
                    _LOGGER.info("A body is sent with the request")
                else:
                    _LOGGER.info("No body was attached to the request")                  
``` 
to at least indicate that something was sent or not.

This is pseudo-code, the PR should think about data/files and all possible kind of body a request can hold.

items.title: TopicSender unable to recover after timeout

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: customer-reported
labels.description: Issues that are reported by GitHub users external to the Azure organization.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
- **Package Name**:
azure-servicebus 
- **Package Version**: 
0.50.2
- **Operating System**:
Experienced in Docker image `python:3.8-slim-buster` as well as locally on macOS 10.14.6
- **Python Version**: 
3.8

**Describe the bug**
Trying to send a message after the 240 s of inactivity results in various errors.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Get a sender `sender = TopicClient.from_connection_string(connection_string).get_sender()`
2. Send a message (msg1)
3. Wait 241 s
4. Send a message (msg2)

**Observed behavior**
The send operation errors with 

```
ErrorCodes.ConnectionCloseForced: The connection was inactive for more than the allowed 240000 milliseconds and is closed by container
```

Usually, `sender.send()` of subsequent messages does succeed, however see **Additional context**

**Expected behavior**
Sender reconnects after experiencing the timed out connection, and sends msg2 transparently.

**Additional context**
The application is a small python program running in a container.
It reads messages from a subscription. Reads some data. Sends a message to another topic.
Both receiver and sender are instantiated on startup and not manually (by us) replaced.
Messages sometimes come in more than 240s apart.
We are not seeing any warnings or errors from the receiver.

From looking through logs, I see that the sender _usually_ recovers after failing the current message, and sends subsequent messages successfully. 

I'm am very unsure whether the following is in fact related or another issue, but I include it just in case:
Occasionally the sender enters an untenable state, where all subsequent send attempts fail with 
```
Handler failed: The supplied authentication has already been consumed by another connection. Please create a fresh instance.
```

This first happened after a few weeks of running continuously, with only occasional errors of the previously mentioned type.
More specifically this started on Jul 14 around 8.00 (Copenhagen time).
The problem went away after restarting the container, but reappeared on Jul 18 around 10.04. This time the error train looks to have begun with the aforementioned timeout error.

**Workarounds tried**
Catching the error, I have tried both calling `sender.reconnect()` and then re-sending the message and creating a new sender and resending the message. Both attempts result in errors stating that the message was already settled.

My current – so far seemingly working – workaround is to cache the last timestamp of activity and recreate the sender before sending a message if the last activity was more than 210s ago (240s - 30s margin).

items.body:
1.
Sample [datalake_samples_instantiate_client_async.py](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/storage/azure-storage-file-datalake/samples/datalake_samples_instantiate_client_async.py)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57166602/88141734-bffbdf80-cc26-11ea-8ac1-5b0272691ac3.png)

Suggestion:
This is an asynchronous sample, so asynchronous methods should be used.
Update the code to :
```
import asyncio
import os


class InstSamplesAsync(object):

    connection_string = os.environ['AZURE_STORAGE_CONNECTION_STRING']
    
    async def instantiate_directory_client_from_conn_str_async():
        # [START instantiate_directory_client_from_conn_str_async]
        from azure.storage.filedatalake.aio import DataLakeDirectoryClient
        DataLakeDirectoryClient.from_connection_string(connection_string, "myfilesystem", "mydirectory")
        # [END instantiate_directory_client_from_conn_str_async]


    async def instantiate_file_client_from_conn_str_async():
        # [START instantiate_file_client_from_conn_str_async]
        from azure.storage.filedatalake.aio import DataLakeFileClient
        DataLakeFileClient.from_connection_string(connection_string, "myfilesystem", "mydirectory", "myfile")
        # [END instantiate_file_client_from_conn_str_async]


async def main():
    sample = InstSamplesAsync()
    await instantiate_directory_client_from_conn_str_async()
    await instantiate_file_client_from_conn_str_async()


if __name__ == '__main__':
    loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
    loop.run_until_complete(main())
```

2.Sample [datalake_samples_file_system.py](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/master/sdk/storage/azure-storage-file-datalake/samples/datalake_samples_file_system.py#L118)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57166602/88141868-110bd380-cc27-11ea-92b7-e58b95b11150.png)

Reason:
Run this sample , encountered the error: azure.core.exceptions.ResourceNotFoundError: The specified container does not exist.

Suggestion:
Update the first `myfilesystem` to `mypathfilesystem`.
Update the second `myfilesystem` to `myclientfilesystem`.

items.body:
```python
# setup.py
# python: 2.7.5
# setuptools: 40.6.2

from setuptools import setup


setup(
    install_requires=[
        'azure==1.0.3',
    ],
)
```
When I use a command '**python setup.py install**' using the above `setup.py`, the `import azure` statement refers to `.../site-packages/azure_nspkg-3.0.2-py2.7.egg/azure/` directory. But, the directory has not any submodules like `storage`. So, it raises `ImportError: no module named storage` if I states `import azure.storage`.

When I tried it python 3.x, it worked well. But, I should use the python 2.7 and `setuptools`.
So, I want to know how to use the `azure` package in python 2.7 with `setuptools`.

items.title: Can not install azure-identity with poetry with --allow-prereleases

labels.name: customer-reported
labels.description: Issues that are reported by GitHub users external to the Azure organization.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

items.body:
- **Package Name**: azure-identity
- **Package Version**: 1.4.0b6
- **Operating System**: Ubuntu 20.04
- **Python Version**: 3.8

**Describe the bug**
When using [Poetry](https://python-poetry.org/) to manage a python project. Installing the current pre-release version of azure-identity fails with a max recursion depth error.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Install poetry
   ```bash
   pip install poetry
   ```
1. Set up a new poetry project in an empty directory
   ```bash
   mkdir azure-identity-test
   poetry init -n # -n specifies non-interactive and uses defaults
   ```
1. Install the prerelease of `azure-identity`
   ```bash
   poetry add azure-identity --allow-prereleases
   ```
1. Observe the following output
   ```
   Creating virtualenv azure-identity-test-ZMyS48q3-py3.8 in /home/nzsmartie/.cache/pypoetry/virtualenvs
   Using version ^1.4.0-beta.6 for azure-identity
   
   Updating dependencies
   Resolving dependencies... (8.4s)
   
   [RecursionError]
   maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object
   ```

**Expected behavior**
The package would install without issues along with its dependencies.

**Additional context**
Poetry has difficulty with multiple same name dependencies with different version requirements: https://github.com/python-poetry/poetry/issues/1238

When enabling verbosity as the package is installed. there's an almost never ending loop of the following issue being produced.

```
Different requirements found for portalocker (>=1.0,<2.0) and portalocker (>=1.6,<2.0).
```
as produced by:
```bash
poetry add azure-identity --allow-prereleases -vvv
```

Both [Azurite](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-use-azurite) and the [Azure storage emulator](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-use-emulator) assume the `'http://127.0.0.1:1000/devstoreaccount1'` account URL, but it seems like the Azure Python SDK sadly does not support this.

items.title: Simplify CI logs to improve debugging

labels.name: EngSys
labels.description: This issue is responsible by the Engineering System team.

items.body:
CI currently runs 5 different tests in parallel when running scheduled job and this makes it harder to find what exactly has failed due to current logging when tox is running in parallel. We need to simplify this logging to make it easier to find failures and reasons.

Please find below email thread for more info

```
Yes, that’s accurate. The invocation of tox is in serial (one package at a time), but the running of the environments for each package is in parallel. 

It’s dual core, so that means that 2 are invoking at a time.

If we want to split the steps up so that we have:

•	Run Dev Tests (sdist and whl)
•	Run Import Tests (depends)
•	Run MinMaxTests (mindep,maxdep)
•	Run Regression (currently another job, let’s leave this out FOR NOW)

So if we were to just change nothing else other than splitting up the invocations, we’ll end up hurting our invocation time. I don’t necessarily think it’ll be bad, but we definitely should try a prototype of this for say, storage. Here’s an example of just that. This isn’t ready for checkin, but will give us a good idea about how long it will extend the runtime.

I do think on the outset, we would be better served by doing the following. 

1.	Really clean up the test output. Tox itself shouldn’t echo any logs unless there is a failure. Attach tox logs to builds as artifact.
2.	Suppress error output until end, provide single formatted report at end of test phase

@Praveen Kuttappan any other thoughts on improvements to diagnosability?

Thanks,
Scott

From: Laurent Mazuel <lmazuel@microsoft.com> 
Sent: Tuesday, June 30, 2020 3:38 PM
To: Scott Beddall <scbedd@microsoft.com>; Praveen Kuttappan <Praveen.Marottickal@microsoft.com>
Cc: Scott Kurtzeborn <scotk@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: CI kudos and retrospectives

Do I understand correctly that “tox -e whl,sdist,mindep,maxdep,imports” are ran in parallel right now? And that splitting in ADO steps would break that?


From: Scott Beddall <scbedd@microsoft.com> 
Sent: Tuesday, June 30, 2020 3:01 PM
To: Praveen Kuttappan <Praveen.Marottickal@microsoft.com>; Laurent Mazuel <lmazuel@microsoft.com>
Cc: Scott Kurtzeborn <scotk@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: CI kudos and retrospectives

There are definitely improvements we can make as to the output. I can easily be sold on that 😊 

Currently, we test tox environments in parallel in the “Run-Tests” step, but invoke them in serial.

Essentially:

-	cd /sdk/storage/azure-storage-blobs 
-	tox -e whl,sdist,mindep,maxdep,imports

The only way we can split these up (which I do not protest against) is to add an `setup_execute_tests` for each one of these environments. That will have a fairly negative impact on our runtimes as implemented right now. We’ll need to figure out how to make multiple tox invocations run at the same time. 

Another thing I think we should do is to disable detailed logs (but attach them to the build output) unless there is an ERROR

The output of setup_execute_tests should also be more terse in general, outside of maybe “pip freeze” and the like.

Thanks,
Scott

From: Praveen Kuttappan <Praveen.Marottickal@microsoft.com> 
Sent: Tuesday, June 30, 2020 10:50 AM
To: Laurent Mazuel <lmazuel@microsoft.com>; Scott Beddall <scbedd@microsoft.com>
Cc: Scott Kurtzeborn <scotk@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: CI kudos and retrospectives

Thanks for this great feedback. I will discuss with Scott and come up with a plan on your suggestions. To begin with, I will have a wiki created about all checks we do in Engsys for python.

Thanks and regards,
Praveen

From: Laurent Mazuel <lmazuel@microsoft.com> 
Sent: Tuesday, June 30, 2020 10:38 AM
To: Scott Beddall <scbedd@microsoft.com>; Praveen Kuttappan <Praveen.Marottickal@microsoft.com>
Cc: Scott Kurtzeborn <scotk@microsoft.com>
Subject: CI kudos and retrospectives

Hey Scott, Praveen,

Last night the regression “mindependency” CI found a regression that was merged in “azure-mgmt-core” part of a PR of yesterday. This was a 100% correct discovery, and I’m really relieved that the CI was there, especially since the impact would have been wide and include the China team. I thought it deserves an email to thank you again for that system, and re-iterate how I think this kind of CI steps are important for Python 😊

When you were investigated what happened with Izzy, I noted two things I wanted to discuss:
-	Izzy was not aware a regression system was in place, which makes the understanding of what happened confusing to her
-	Even when I told her, it’s lost in the middle of a step log, and she couldn’t find it.

I have a few suggestions I want to debate with you:
-	Could we make an inventory of what the engsys is doing:
o	What kind of checks exists (mypy, pylint, unittests, regression, shared req, etc.)
o	What kind of CI exists (PR, nightly scheduled, etc.)
o	Maybe a giant table to cross all that?
Maybe it exists already, but I wasn’t able to find it myself on the internal wiki if that’s the case.
-	Could we split CI in more steps. I understand the limitation of agents, but could we make more steps without making it slower? “Run Tests” to do both unittests + mindependency was confusing
-	Could we imagine a brown bag series once we get clarity of docs, to be sure the whole team is on the same page. I’m no fool, I’m fairly sure this would need to be done every 6 months or so to keep up and refresh people memory.

Again, thanks for the regression catch 😉
Let me know your thoughts,

Thanks!

Laurent

Why does GraphRbacManagementClient from azure-sdk-python call to Azure AD Graph API (https://graph.windows.net/) and does not support Microsoft Graph (https://graph.microsoft.com/)?

So what will happen to this library? There is a plan to refactor?

items.title: Servicebus Track2 UAMQP may need changes to support not closing receiver when generator terminates.

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

items.body:
Truth in advertising.  We've been relying on lazy-reopening to ensure a user could consume the generator, interrupt, then resume consumption, but it might be a more proper semantic to simply not close it unless explicitly closed (or the context manager ends).

This may require UAMQP-side changes as well.
